subheader.en-US: Understanding the mechanisms, tactics or cues used by different types of killer whales

copy.en-US:
As a species that spends their entire lives with their families, it is remarkable how good killer whales are at avoiding inbreeding. The Conservation Genetics Lab is trying to understand the mechanisms, tactics or cues used by different types of killer whales that help them choose a suitable, unrelated mate.

How do resident killer whales avoid inbreeding if sons and daughters stay with their mother all their life?

Dr. Lance Barrett-Lennard, completed a long-term study that helped to answer this and other questions that had long eluded killer whale researchers. By analyzing DNA from tiny skin samples taken from more than 300 killer whales in B.C. and Alaska, Dr. Barrett-Lennard could determine two things: paternities (who the fathers are) and how communities of killer whales are related to one another. His study showed that resident killer whales not only avoid mating with pod-mates, but that they have a complex mating system that prevents breeding between other close relatives and closely resembles traditional marriage systems in some indigenous human populations.

Paternity tests showed that mating never occurs within matrilines, rarely if ever occurs within pods and usually occurs between the members of different clans. Clan-based marriage systems were also the rule for coastal First Nations peoples in B.C., and existed in Australian aboriginal groups and in various indigenous societies in China and Africa.

In Residents, there is a clear link between the calls that killer whales make and who they mate with. Killer whales tend to mate with partners that don't sound like themselves. This makes sense, because Dr. Barrett-Lennard also showed that the more similar the dialects of two groups, the more related they are.

Bigg’s (transient) and resident killer whales represent distinct lineages with little or no exchange of individuals or interbreeding. The differences are so great that they have likely been isolated genetically for many thousands of years.

Now the Marine Mammal Research Program is building on this work by investigating how Bigg’s killer whales choose their mates. As in the previous study, the first step is to look at paternity. Crossman and Miscampbell are testing parentage in an extensive set of DNA samples from male, female, and juvenile Bigg’s killer whales. The results of this study could help to bolster the non-genetic evidence supporting two distinct populations of Bigg’s killer whales in B.C.

title.en-US: Conservation Genetics

copy.en-US:
In the Conservation Genetics Lab, the Marine Mammal Research team uses DNA as a tool to help better understand marine mammal species and populations, which ultimately aids in conservation and management efforts.

One of the many challenges critically-endangered populations face is the progressive loss of genetic diversity from inbreeding. For many years, the Marine Mammal Research Program has studied genetic diversity in killer whale populations off the west coast of British Columbia. The program’s sample collection has grown through the years, with help of collaborators, to include over 700 unique biopsy samples (small samples of tissue) of killer whales in the Northeast Pacific. While most of the program’s genetics work is focused on killer whales, the team also analyzes DNA samples of other marine mammals found in British Columbia waters – many of these samples come from stranded carcasses. These samples are being analyzed to better understand how population size affects diversity loss in this species, determine the extent of the problem and to provide more information that can be included in the development of management plans help develop conservation plans going forward.

title.en-US: Marine Mammals

subheader.en-US: Studying the health of marine mammals for a flourishing ocean

overlay.en-US: Studying the health of marine mammals for flourishing oceans

copy.en-US:
Since the mid-1980s, the Marine Mammal Research Program has conducted conservation-oriented research on killer whales, belugas and other marine mammals. The program focuses on long-term studies of marine mammal populations and the threats these at-risk populations face. The program’s particular strengths are in cetacean distribution and abundance, acoustic behaviour, population genetics and, photogrammetric monitoring of health and condition of killer whales and humpback whales. Many of the Marine Mammal Research Program’s members are part of collaborative projects with other research institutes, and serve on various advisory committees and expert panels concerned with the conservation of marine mammals and their habitats.

Much of the Marine Mammal Research Program’s genetics work and killer whale field research is funded by the [Wild Killer Whale Adoption Program](http://www.killerwhale.org/), which raises funds through symbolic adoptions of British Columbia’s killer whales.

title.en-US: Coastal Ocean Research Institute

subheader.en-US: Conducting scientific research in support of ocean conservation

copy.en-US: The Coastal Ocean Research Institute (CORI) conducts leading and collaborative research on ocean sciences, evaluates human impacts on coastal environments, and integrates information to produce high level assessments of the state of the coastal ocean. CORI’s research team is at the forefront of a number of conservation science initiatives, and seeks to document conservation threats in ways that enable mitigation, protection and/or recovery of aquatic species and habitats. CORI staff conduct research in the field and in the lab, using novel study designs and cutting-edge technologies. CORI is headquartered at the Vancouver Aquarium in Vancouver, and with a laboratory facility at the Pacific Science Enterprise Centre in West Vancouver.

teamCopy.en-US: Meet the passionate and committed scientists behind the Coastal Ocean Research Institute

publicationCopy.en-US: Explore the Coastal Ocean Research Institute research archive

projectTitle.en-US: Noise Impacts on St. Lawrence Belugas

subheader.en-US: St Lawrence Estuary beluga population was listed as endangered under the Species at Risk Act

copy.en-US: With just under 900 individuals, the St Lawrence Estuary beluga population was listed as endangered under the Species at Risk Act (SARA) in September 2016.  The population has been steadily declining since the early 2000s, a trend that may be accentuated by a recent unprecedented increase in calf mortality. Various factors have been proposed to play a role: climate change and shortage of food supplies, toxic algal blooms, pollution, and increased underwater noise and anthropogenic disturbance. Marine Mammal Research Program researchers are working with GREMM (Group for Research and Education on Marine Mammals) to study underwater noise in a key summering habitat of this endangered population and investigate its potential impacts on beluga communication, [particularly on the system of contact calls used between mothers and their dependent calves](https://www.aquablog.ca/2016/09/unravelling-the-mystery-of-endangered-beluga-whales/).  Results of this study will contribute to developing sound mitigation efforts in critical beluga habitat.

title.en-US: Biology, Ecology, and Health of Marine Mammals

copy.en-US: All marine mammal species are subjected to human-caused threats that may impact the health of their populations and impede their recovery. The Marine Mammal Research Program’s current projects and initiatives involve monitoring and protecting marine mammals in regards to issues related to population status, prey availability, underwater noise, contaminants, ship strike avoidance and effectiveness of mitigation measures.

subheader.en-US: Ocean Wise Research delivers science in support of healthy aquatic species and healthy oceans

introCopy.en-US: Ocean Wise Research contributes to knowledge and understanding of individuals, populations and habitats through a combination of studies carried out in the wild and with the animals living at the Vancouver Aquarium. Field research is largely carried out under the auspices of the Coastal Ocean Research Institute (CORI), while collections-based research is carried out at the Vancouver Aquarium. In this way, Ocean Wise Research contributes to the well-being of aquatic animals and their habitats, and informs how best we as humans can minimise our impact on coastal environments. Ocean Wise Research discoveries are shared through scientific publications, media, social media and public lectures, and through the provision of expert advice to governments, industry and non-governmental organizations.

firstCopy.en-US: Ocean Wise Research is home to more than 30 researchers engaged in ocean science and the conservation of ocean life.

secondCopy.en-US: Ocean Wise scientists regularly share stories about their work.

thirdCopy.en-US: Ocean Wise research staff publish extensively in the international scientific literature.

title.en-US: Vancouver Aquarium Research

subheader.en-US: A comprehensive scientific program that contributes to conservation planning in the wild and enhances the care of animals at the Vancouver Aquarium

copy.en-US: Research at the Vancouver Aquarium is conducted by world-class scientists, biologists, veterinarians, animal care technicians and scholars. For more than 60 years, scientists at the Vancouver Aquarium have been delivering insight into the natural world. Situated on the shoreline of Stanley Park in British Columbia, the Vancouver Aquarium is ideally positioned to conduct research that provides real world relevance. The knowledge acquired through these initiatives contributes to enhanced animal care, increased understanding of the biology of diverse species and effective conservation planning. Vancouver Aquarium researchers explore a wide range of topics including veterinary sciences, nutrition, life history, and habitat needs.

teamCopy.en-US: Meet the passionate and committed scientists behind Vancouver Aquarium Research

publicationCopy.en-US: Explore the Vancouver Aquarium Research publication archive

title.en-US: Marine Mammal Energetics and Ecology

subheader.en-US: Many populations of marine mammals, both in the Pacific Northwest and around the globe, are declining or under pressure from rapid environmental changes

overlay.en-US: Research with trained animals to facilitate conservation

copy.en-US:
Many populations of marine mammals – both in the Pacific Northwest and around the globe – are declining or under pressure from rapid environmental changes. While studies in the wild are important for understanding how these animals are impacted by changes in their natural habitat, many to conduct research with trained animals, under precise scientific conditions, through an international group of scientists. The goal of the Marine Mammal Energetics and Ecology Program (MMEEP) is to conduct research under precise scientific conditions, with trained animals, to directly facilitate the conservation of populations in the wild.

Major areas of research include bioenergetics (energy requirements and use), nutrition (determining the value of different prey), measures of health (and how to evaluate it in the wild), and the development and testing of new tools and techniques to study animals in the wild. 

MMEEP engages in research with all of the Aquarium’s marine mammal collection animals (plus penguins) by an international group of scientists.

title.en-US: Ocean Pollution

subheader.en-US: Determining the sources and consequences of ocean pollution

overlay.en-US: Determining the sources and consequences of ocean pollution

copy.en-US: There is an estimated 250,000 commercial chemicals in large-scale use around the world. Many of these threaten ocean life, including fish, birds and marine mammals. The focus of the Ocean Pollution Research Program is to determine the sources and consequences of ocean pollution, communicating results to stakeholder and the public and to provide guidance on solutions in the form of best practices, consumer choices and policies.

title.en-US: PollutionTracker

copy.en-US:
### An integrated, partner-supported pollution monitoring network for coastal British Columbia

Coastal British Columbia (BC) is home to the world’s most contaminated marine mammals (SARA-listed Bigg’s and Southern Resident Killer Whales), a legacy of pulp mill-associated dioxins and furans, and localized pollutant hotspots and contaminated sites. Despite this, there has been no integrated coast-wide monitoring of marine pollution in BC. PollutionTracker was launched in 2015 to address this gap and help answer an important question: How polluted is our ocean? PollutionTracker is using high resolution analysis to report the levels and trends of hundreds of contaminants of concern in mussels and nearshore subtidal sediment along the entire coast of BC. This long-term dataset will help inform source identification, pollution priorities, best practices, and natural resource management in BC.

title.en-US: Ocean Watch

subheader.en-US: Ocean Watch reports provide snapshots of coastal ocean health

overlay.en-US: Ocean Watch reports provide snapshots of ocean health

copy.en-US: Howe Sound is a remarkable blend of wilderness and accessibility. It sits directly adjacent to the growing metropolis of Vancouver, yet also contains fantastic wild places and natural recreational opportunities.

title.en-US: Howe Sound

copy.en-US: The seaward part of the famed Sea-to-Sky country.

title.en-US: Howe Sound Biodiversity

subheader.en-US: Coastal ecology and biodiversity research in the context of global change

overlay.en-US: Ecology and biodiversity in the context of global change

copy.en-US: Howe Sound Biodiversity research is about coastal ecology, nearshore biodiversity, and underwater natural history, primarily in Howe Sound, British Columbia. Adjacent to Vancouver, Howe Sound is one of North America's southernmost fjords and is home to more than 650 different species of fish and invertebrates. Faced with threats like depleted groundfish stocks and historical contamination, it provides a useful case study for understanding changes in coastal ecology as pressures like development and climate change pressure continue into the future. With over 35 years of marine research experience, the program is one of the longest-running ecological monitoring programs in the Strait of Georgia.

title.en-US: Biodiversity in the Context of Global Change

copy.en-US: To make informed decisions on how to interact with the marine environment, it is important to have accurate methods for evaluating how human activities and climate change affect biodiversity. Continued efforts have helped to build one of the longest running data sets of underwater natural history in British Columbia.  Such long-term data is critical in establishing a reference point for documenting changes, whether changes are due to climate change, human interaction or natural patterns.

projectTitle.en-US: Long Term Seabed Biodiversity Surveys Using SCUBA

title.en-US: Arctic

subheader.en-US: Improving our understanding of how today’s rapid changes impact both wildlife and the people who rely on it for social, cultural and nutritional wellbeing

copy.en-US: From research on beluga acoustics and collaborative work on narwhal distribution and movement, to subtidal marine ecology, Ocean Wise scientists and staff conduct and contribute to important Arctic scientific research. Our work recognizes the important connections people in the North have with the natural environment, and we regularly collaborate with Arctic Indigenous communities to ensure our work is both relevant and meets the needs of Canada’s northernmost residents.

teamCopy.en-US: Meet the passionate and committed scientists behind our arctic research

publicationCopy.en-US: Explore the arctic research publication archive

subheader.en-US: Ikaarvic works with youth to build connections between scientists and Inuit communities

copy.en-US:
The word “[Ikaarvik](http://ikaarvik.org/)” means “bridge” in Inuktitut. Youth in Arctic communities become the bridge between research and their communities, exploring the strengths of both Indigenous Traditional Knowledge and science as ways to understand the natural world and working with their communities to identify and act on local research priorities.

Some projects and partners include:
- Community-based microplastics sampling - Kugluktuk, NU; Oceans North
- Coppermine River health monitoring - Kugluktuk, NU; University of Waterloo
- Arctic corridors and Northern Voices - Gjoa Haven & Pond Inlet, NU; Salluit, Nunavik; University of Ottawa
- Invasive species - Pond Inlet, NU; Salluit, Nunavik; Fisheries and Oceans Canada
- SIKU Inuit Knowledge Social Mapping Platform - Gjoa Haven, NU; Arctic Eider Society

For more information about Ikaarvik, visit [http://ikaarvik.org/](http://ikaarvik.org/)

title.en-US: Plastics

subheader.en-US: Cutting-edge science & technology to document the source, distribution and impact of plastic and microplastics in the world’s oceans

copy.en-US: Microplastics, micro-scale plastic fragments, are new and unique environmental contaminants. Their presence in the ocean can be attributed to fragmentation of larger plastic debris entering them at an unprecedented scale (8 million metric tonnes per year) or to direct inputs from land sources such as wastewater or stormwater discharge. They are now recognized to have a widespread presence in the world’s oceans, from coastal waters and sediments to aquatic organisms such as fish, zooplankton and mussels to the most remote regions on the planet such as open-ocean wasters of Arctic and Southern Ocean. Yet, our understanding of the potential biological and ecological consequences of environmental microplastic contamination is severely limited. Scientist at Ocean Wise conduct field- and lab-based research to better understand the the abundance, sources and environmental fate of microplastics, with a focus on the coastal British Columbia and the Arctic ecosystem. Our research initiatives aim to provide a synoptic view of the nature of the oceanic microplastic contamination to help inform stakeholders, decision-makers, industry and the consumers.

teamCopy.en-US: Meet the passionate and committed scientists behind our plastics research

publicationCopy.en-US: Explore the plastics research publication archive

subheader.en-US: Take the #BePlasticWise pledge

title.en-US: Special Places

subheader.en-US: Science to enable the protection of valued coastal ocean habitats, areas and regions for future generations

copy.en-US: Healthy coastal environments provide food, recreational and cultural opportunities to communities. Some places are deemed to be particularly valuable, because of unique biological or geographic attributes that support communities. Conducting place-based research is key to mapping out critical habitat, parks, reserves, and marine protected areas, and ultimately critical to the protection of vital biological resources. Ocean Wise research teams are heavily engaged in research in a number of areas, with the goal of understanding and protecting unique features along the coast.

teamCopy.en-US: Meet the passionate and committed scientists behind our research on special places

publicationCopy.en-US: Explore the Special Places research archive

subheader.en-US: Long-term biodiversity studies

copy.en-US:
Atl’Kitsem/Howe Sound is an ecologically rich marine area that lies within the unceded territory of the Squamish Nation and sits directly adjacent to the growing metropolis of Vancouver. It exemplifies the opportunities of coastal development and the associated risks for ecological integrity, particularly with respect to pressures such as development, population growth, and climate change. Many jurisdictions, communities, and groups aspire to protect and improve Howe Sound’s ocean health.

[Howe Sound Biodiversity](https://research.ocean.org/program/howe-sound-research-conservation "Howe Sound Biodiversity")
[Ocean Watch: Howe Sound Edition](http://oceanwatch.ca/howesound/ "Ocean Watch: Howe Sound Edition")

title.en-US: Species Under Threat

subheader.en-US: Research that informs the protection and recovery of threatened aquatic species

copy.en-US: Aquatic species are affected by numerous anthropogenic (human-caused) factors that negatively impact their critical life processes. These include degradation or destruction of habitats, fishing or hunting reduction in prey availability and quality, disturbance from underwater noise and the proximity of vessels, toxic contaminants, and entanglement in fishing gear. These threats reduce a species’ ability to forage and reproduce, which ultimately affects its ability to maintain healthy populations. Ocean Wise’s Research team explores a variety of these issues and their effects on aquatic populations.

teamCopy.en-US: Meet the passionate and committed scientists behind our research

publicationCopy.en-US: Explore the Species Under Threat research archive

subheader.en-US: Threatened by lack of prey, underwater noise, physical disturbance and pollution

copy.en-US: Three genetically, culturally, ecologically and morphologically-distinct types of killer whales inhabit coastal waters in the northeast Pacific.  Members of the most abundant type, known as residents, prey on fish, preferentially Chinook salmon. Two distinct populations of resident killer whales inhabit British Columbia waters, the so-called  Northern and Southern Residents. Threatened by lack of prey, underwater noise, physical disturbance and pollution, Northern Residents are listed as threatened under Canada’s Species at Risk Act and Southern Residents are listed as endangered. To help monitor the health of these two populations, the Coastal Ocean Research Institute’s Marine Mammal Research team is assessing changes in the whales’ body condition and nutritional status in relation to fluctuations in salmon abundance.
Meet the passionate and committed scientists behind our research

title.en-US: About Ocean Wise Research

subheader.en-US: Ocean Wise Research is home to more than 30 researchers committed to pursuing science in support of ocean conservation.

copy.en-US:
# Coastal Ocean Research Institute

CORI maintains a major laboratory capacity at the Pacific Science Enterprise Centre (PSEC) in West Vancouver, with a focus on providing strong new insights into ocean sciences and ocean conservation. CORI operates five programs: Ocean Pollution, Marine Mammals, Howe Sound Biodiversity, the Plastics Lab and Ocean Watch. CORI deploys research teams to the Canadian Arctic, the NE Pacific, the St Lawrence estuary and internationally to work with communities, collect samples and better understand the nature of our ocean ecosystems.

# Vancouver Aquarium Research

Vancouver Aquarium Research pursues investigations to ensure the best care of its collections and to inform on lessons learned for the conservation of populations in the wild. Vancouver Aquarium Research operates five programs: veterinary sciences, marine mammal energetics, frog propagation, fish propagation and jellyfish propagation.

![Ocean Wise Research - Unlocking the mysteries about the marine world](//images.ctfassets.net/fsquhe7zbn68/3g2iRVGoxWGykSyOeG24kY/c80615fa03e0bf5b7668138729c9ba61/2015_09_16_VX-83269_20150728-VV-CI-372c_lowimage.jpg)

imageAttribution.en-US: Photo: Ocean Wise and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration

subheader.en-US: B.C. is home to two populations of resident killer whales

copy.en-US:
B.C. is home to two populations of resident killer whales, one in southern B.C. with fewer than 80 individuals (listed as endangered) and the other in more northerly waters with fewer than 300 individuals (threatened).  Marine Mammal Research Program researchers have helped colleagues in the Cetacean Research Program at Fisheries and Oceans Canada monitor births, deaths and distribution of these populations for over three decades.

Marine Mammal Research Program researchers work with colleagues from NOAA’s Southwest Fisheries Science Center on a study that uses drones to monitor the body condition, pregnancy status and health of resident killer whales in B.C. and northern Washington State. The team takes high-resolution aerial photographs of the whales using a small-unmanned hexacopter, and then uses a technique called photogrammetry to measure their length, width and shape. These data are then used to assess overall condition (fatness—a reliable indicator of health), pregnancy status and growth rates. The team then examines changes in these measures within and between years in relation to prey abundance. Since resident killer whales forage primarily on Chinook salmon — which vary in abundance greatly between years — the study is able to examine when and how often the whales are nutritionally-challenged, which has important implications for fisheries management in both the U.S. and Canada.

In 2014, Dr. Lance Barrett-Lennard, and his long-time colleagues, Drs. John Durban (NOAA’s Southwest Fisheries Science Centre) and Holly Fearnbach (SR3– Sealife Response, Rehabilitation and Research) began an innovative collaborative study to assess the body condition of northern resident killer whales. Expanded to include southern residents in 2015, the project uses a boat-launched, hexacopter drone to obtain high-resolution aerial photographs of killer whales. Measurements from the photos provide invaluable data about body condition (fatness), sex (if not already known), state of pregnancy, and comparisons with biopsy-based measurements of health and contaminants using novel methods developed by our scientists. The project was recommended by a bilateral scientific panel investigating the impact of fisheries on southern resident killer whales and provide an early warning system whereby the impact of food shortages or potentially other events such as disease or pollutants can be detected before they become lethal. Data from the study, which has now completed its third field season, is being used to inform fisheries management actions, fish conservation actions, and will be used in the development of measures to reduce the impact of chronic pollutants and catastrophic events such as oils spills.

projectTitle.en-US: Sound-Centered Species in Today's Noisy Arctic

subheader.en-US: Belugas and narwhals use sound for nearly every aspect of their lives

copy.en-US:
A decline of Arctic ice as a result of climate change has opened northern passages for navigation, increasing the exposure of arctic marine mammals to anthropogenic sounds and stressors. Belugas and narwhals use sound for nearly every aspect of their lives: to communicate, to maintain group cohesion, to navigate, to locate prey, and to avoid predators. Consequently, underwater noise pollution from a number of sources is one of the most pervasive threats these species face in much of their range, potentially leading to significant disruptions of their behaviour and impairing their ability to communicate efficiently.  Marine Mammal Research Program’s Dr. Valeria Vergara leads studies on beluga and narwhal communication that span various Arctic areas, addressing the challenges such sound-centered species face in their increasingly noisy environment. These field studies pair simultaneous aerial imagery and underwater acoustic data, an innovative marriage of technologies that facilitates the investigation of a species' communication, behaviour and responses to anthropogenic noise with an unprecedented level of detail.

For a first-hand account of Dr. Vergara’s Arctic field-work, you can read [Field Notes from Arctic Watch](http://vancouversun.com/author/jenniferkolbuc2014) and [Field Notes from the Churchill Estuary](https://www.aquablog.ca/2017/09/arctic-summer-field-notes-from-churchill-river-estuary/)

subheader.en-US: Monitoring changes to the community of microorganisms and pathogens in humpback whales

copy.en-US:
Using an unmanned-hexacopter, the Marine Mammal Research Program conducts humpback whale photogrammetry and blow sample collection for health and condition monitoring. The blow samples are being used to better understand the community of microorganisms that inhabit the respiratory tracks of apparently healthy whales. By acquiring baseline information on the normal composition of microorganisms found in healthy humpback whale blows, researchers can monitor changes to the community of microorganisms and recognize potential pathogens – potentially introduced from anthropogenic sources such as wastewater or sewage discharge – in individuals and or the population.

Decimated in the first half of the 20th century by industrial-scale whaling, B.C.’s humpback whale population is showing encouraging signs of recovery. Despite this, it is still listed as threatened and is highly vulnerable to changes in ocean productivity (which are highly sensitive to climate change) and catastrophic events such as oil spills. In 2016, Dr. Lance Barrett-Lennard, and his long-time colleagues, Drs. John Durban (NOAA’s Southwest Fisheries Science Centre) and Holly Fearnbach (SR3– Sealife Response, Rehabilitation and Research) began a multi-year study of season and inter-annual changes in their body condition, to assess the effects of fluctuating productivity on their health, growth rates and calf production. The teams uses similar photogrammetric methods to those described for the killer whale health monitoring project, with the added element of using the drone to capture samples of exhaled breath for assessment of viral, bacterial and fungal organisms that have the potential to affect health. As with the killer whale study, the project is intended to provide an early warning system whereby the impact of food shortages, disease and chronic and catastrophic pollutants can be detected at sub-lethal levels. In addition, the blow-sampling component helps veterinary researchers better understand the community of microorganisms present in apparently healthy whales, so that they can interpret the significance of similar and different microorganisms in sick or dead whales—and in the process better understand causes of mortality.

subheader.en-US: Describing the seasonal diet of harbour seals in the Strait of Georgia

copy.en-US:
While most of the marine mammal research team focused on cetacean research, the Marine Mammal Research Program’s Chad Nordstrom assists with a pinniped diet-monitoring study conducted by Fisheries and Oceans Canada in collaboration with the Pacific Salmon Foundation during 2016/17. The study aimed to describe the seasonal diet of harbour seals in the Strait of Georgia, both inside and outside of estuaries. Nordstrom and colleagues collected scat samples from April – November 2016 and April – May 2017 at both estuary and non-estuary sites within the Salish Sea. Both traditional analysis (identifying species from bones) and newer high-throughput DNA sequencing techniques were used to build a more complete picture of the role seals play as predators in the Salish Sea ecosystem.

Recent studies of harbour seal diets (2012-2014) have been used to estimate the amounts of salmon consumed by seals in the Strait of Georgia. However, these diet data have primarily come from estuary habitats, and may not be representative of all seals. 
The team analyzed 1,317 scat samples collected at an estuary (Cowichan Bay) and seven non-estuary sites from April – November 2016 and April – May 2017 to compare salmon consumption inside and outside of estuaries. Using high-throughput DNA techniques, the team found that seals consumed a wide range of prey (n = 238 species)—with gadids (primarily hake) and forage fish (primarily herring) dominating diets in both habitats (typically >75% of diet when combined).

Analyses are continuing and Nordstrom and his colleagues expect to answer a series of questions including what species and what proportion of salmon are consumed throughout the year. They also expect to estimate the length of salmon taken by seals by measuring the size of salmon bones recovered in scat samples and thereby provide separate diet proportions for adult and juvenile salmonids.
The team expects to see juvenile chinook, and to a lesser extent Coho and chum in the spring with adult chum expected to be more common in the fall. A key question is how widespread is salmon consumption and how the patterns may change between different sites. 
These findings will help to guide models estimating harbour seal related salmon mortality and will allow researchers to consider differences in consumption rates inside and outside of estuaries and between other geographic regions in the Salish Sea.

projectTitle.en-US: Impacts and Mitigation of Underwater Noise

copy.en-US:
Dr. Valeria Vergara joined the Marine Mammal Research team in 2002 as a PhD student with the University of British Columbia. She continued on as a research associate for several years, and is currently a MMRP’s Arctic marine mammal research scientist. Valeria is particularly interested in the communicative and perceptual capacities of marine mammals and the conservation implications of such capacities. Her work during the past 16 years has focused on captive and wild beluga whales, addressing the challenges such sound-centered animals face in their increasingly  noisy environment.

__Areas of Expertise__
- Marine mammal field research
- Arctic cetaceans
- Behavioural ecology
- Bioacoustics
- Impacts of anthropogenic noise on marine mammal behaviour and communication

name.en-US: GREMM (Group for Research and Education on Marine Mammals)

projectTitle.en-US: Genetic Variation Within Marine Mammal Populations

subheader.en-US: Everyone's DNA is a little different, and that is what makes you - you!

copy.en-US:
Looking at variation in DNA both between individuals and within a population can provide clues about the migrations of individuals, how populations are related and levels of inbreeding. Genetic variation is a quantifiable metric that the Marine Mammal Research Program molecular biologists, Carla Crossman and Allyson Miscampbell, use to help answer questions that benefit the conservation of marine mammals.
Everyone’s DNA is a little different, and that is what makes you - you! The differences between the DNA sequences of individuals and between populations can shed light on some really interesting, and important, questions for conservation. The amount of differences between the DNA sequences of a group is called genetic variation. Here are a couple of the Conservation Genetics Lab’s recent projects measuring genetic variation in marine mammal populations:

## Population Structure

How do you decide where one population starts and another one ends? In conservation, when trying to assess threats or impacts to a population, one of the first major steps is trying to understand what it is we are trying to protect. Is it a population of harbor seals that mixes, moves and mingles all along the coast? Is it a population of porpoises that spend all of their time in around a single channel? And with both of these examples, it can be easy to detect hot-spots for species, but it can be harder to tell if individuals are coming and going as tracking the movements of individuals can be difficult.
One way to track the movements of individuals and the fidelity of individuals to certain locations is by using genetics. By comparing DNA sequences of individuals sampled over a large area, you can assess whether more similar sequences are spatially grouped or if they are scattered over the whole study area. This can help define if a large group of animals actually consists of two or more smaller populations or if a single population occupies the whole region. This is called population structure. Marine Mammal Research Program molecular biologists Carla Crossman and Allyson Miscampbell assessed population structure of harbor porpoises throughout the coast of B.C. and found similar sequences were spread almost evenly all along the coast, suggesting a single population of harbour porpoises inhabit these waters.
 
## Adaptive Diversity

There’s part of your DNA found in a group of genes called the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) that helps control different aspects of immune function – needless to say, it’s pretty important. It is part of your DNA that tells your body to fight off different viruses and pathogens so having a lot of variation in this part of your DNA can enable you to fight off more types of viruses and pathogens. Therefore, having more variation can be beneficial, and consequently, if there is lots of variation across the whole population, the chances of the population being able to persist in the face of multiple stressors is increased. This kind of diversity that confers an advantage is known as adaptive diversity.

Marine Mammal Research Program molecular biologists Crossman and Miscampbell compared variation at MHC genes between 12 populations of killer whales in the North Pacific. With some of these populations, like Southern Resident killer whales, having very small population sizes, the team were interested to know how much variation they have compared to larger populations like West Coast Bigg’s (transient) killer whales. Some of the analysis is still underway, but it seems that at least in some genes, Southern Residents have even more variation than in much larger populations suggesting that as long as the population doesn’t stay small for long, they might be able to recover from this bottleneck.

projectTitle.en-US: Genetic Identification of Tissues and Carcasses

subheader.en-US: "Can you help us figure out what this is?"

copy.en-US:
When a dead marine mammal is found on a beach, varying states of decay can make it often hard to identify what you are seeing. With a small piece of skin, muscle or even bone, Marine Mammal Research Program molecular biologists Carla Crossman and Allyson Miscampbell can identify the species of the carcass and in the case of killer whales, even the ecotype. Crossman and Miscampbell can even use tissue collected after a Bigg’s (transient) killer whale attack to help uncover what they ate.

Every once and a while, a tube of marine mammal bits arrives in the mailbox at the Conservation Genetics Lab with a seemingly simple request: “Can you help us figure out what this is?” When a biological blob can’t be identified by traditional ID methods, field scientists turn to genetics to help identify the species of unknown samples.

When a marine mammal dies, the body is often never recovered. It usually sinks to the bottom and a new meal arrives for many bottom-dwelling sea creatures. Occasionally however, the circumstances are such that a carcass makes it to shore. By the time they are found, these carcasses can range from being very fresh to completely rotten. The species can sometimes be obvious, and other times the beach cast body can only be described as a ‘blubbery blob’. However, with a piece of skin, muscle or even bone, Crossman and Miscampbell scan help identify what species has been found.

If the carcass is identifiable as a killer whale, it receives a lot of attention. A dead killer whale on a beach is obviously of great interest and sadness, and one of the first questions is always ‘where did it come from?’ Knowing which population, the animal came from is extremely important to the conservation efforts of these small populations. With a fresh carcass, Southern Residents, Northern Residents and West Coast Bigg’s are identifiable by the markings on the saddle patch and dorsal fin. In some cases, however a dead whale might not be found for some time, and its markings will be unclear. In these instances, Crossman and Miscampbell are called upon as local experts to use DNA to pinpoint the population to which this killer whale once belonged.

Not all of the marine mammal bits the Conservation Genetics Lab receives come from stranded dead animals. Occasionally, killer whale researchers, like Dr. Lance Barrett-Lennard, encounter Bigg’s killer whales enjoying a meal. Often the prey is never seen at the surface, and the only evidence of a kill is scraps of skin, lungs or blubber – and happy killer whales. During these encounters, Dr. Barrett-Lennard or his colleagues will try to collect a small piece of leftover ‘meat’ that has floated to the surface. In the genetics lab, Crossman and Miscampbell can then identify which species the Bigg’s were preying upon.

title.en-US: Conservation Through Citizen Science

copy.en-US:
The Marine Mammal Research Program is the home of the [B.C. Cetacean Sightings Network](http://www.wildwhales.org/), one of Canada’s longest-running and most successful citizen science programs. Since 1999, this program has collected opportunistic sightings of cetaceans (whales, dolphins and porpoises) and sea turtles from coastal citizens to better inform researchers about the distribution, relative abundance and habitat use of these species. Information about the distribution and abundance of a species is key to understanding whether they should be listed as extinct, extirpated, endangered, threatened, at-risk or not-at-risk under the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada (COSEWIC), and if the status of the population is improving, steady or declining. Sightings data provides valuable information about species distribution patterns, which aids in future recovery and management plans for species at risk.

Report your sightings at [Wild Whales](http://wildwhales.org/sightings/)

subheader.en-US: Working collaboratively with the shipping industry, coastal pilots, and the Ports of Prince Rupert and Vancouver

copy.en-US:
Following the positive response garnered by *a Mariners Guide to Whales, Dolphins, and Porpoises of Western Canada*, the Coastal Ocean Research Institute is embarking on another exciting project to mitigate the impacts of vessels on cetaceans in B.C. waters. Working collaboratively with the shipping industry, coastal pilots, and the Ports of Prince Rupert and Vancouver, the Coastal Ocean Research Institute will develop a ‘whale alert’ system that will inform incoming large vessels of real-time cetacean sightings from observers reporting to the Sightings Network’s WhaleReport app. The WhaleReport alert system will only transmit sightings to certain vessel classes (e.g. large, commercial transport). Cetacean presence in shipping lanes will be determined from real-time sightings reports submitted via the WhaleReport app. Messages will alert commercial transport vessels to the presence of cetaceans in their vicinity so they can reduce speed or alter course to reduce the chance of collision and disturbance.

This project, slated for implementation in September 2018, will involve numerous agencies and organizations who will work together to create a comprehensive, coordinated alert system that provides relevant and accurate information to mariners.  Extensive consultation and testing in targeted geographical areas and with specific groups will be conducted to ensure effectiveness before coast-wide application.

subheader.en-US: Marine traffic exposes cetaceans to underwater noise and vessel disturbance

copy.en-US:
The coast of B.C. is home to productive waters, astonishing marine biodiversity and a booming shipping industry. All of this adds up to a very busy ocean. On any given day, trawlers, ecotourism boats, recreational vessels, large tankers and cruise ships can be seen traveling along our coast. Unfortunately, this marine traffic exposes cetaceans to underwater noise and vessel disturbance, increasing their chances of fatal injuries due to ship strikes.

In order to reduce the risk of cetacean-vessel collisions, the Coastal Ocean Research Institute’s B.C. Cetacean Sightings Network collaborated with the Port of Vancouver, Prince Rupert Port Authority and Fisheries and Oceans Canada to release a Mariner’s Guide to Whales, Dolphins and Porpoises of Western Canada. This guide aims to improve environmental awareness of the threats associated with large vessels in the marine transport industry, alert commercial mariners to areas with high densities of cetaceans and inform them of the steps they can take to minimize their impact on cetaceans. By educating mariners transiting B.C. waters, this guide will help to reduce the risk of large vessels striking or disturbing fin whales, killer whales and other at-risk cetaceans.

As marine industry in B.C. continues to grow and the environmental pressures on marine mammals increase, there is an urgent need to mitigate the impacts of ship traffic. By educating and informing mariners, this guide will help to decrease the incidence of ship strikes and reduce vessel disturbance. The guide will also increase the number of sightings reported and improve sighting maps, which will help researchers to better understand and protect cetaceans in B.C. waters!

subheader.en-US: B.C. is host to over 39 designated Whale Trail sites

copy.en-US:
In 2015, the B.C. Cetacean Sightings Network researchers noticed an interesting pattern: they were receiving a significant amount of sighting reports from observers on land, despite the fact that their outreach was targeted almost entirely toward mariners. Inspired by this pattern, the B.C. Cetacean Sightings Network teamed up with the Whale Trail, a Seattle-based organization, to help expand the project throughout B.C. and establish a network of land-based marine mammal viewing sites. After two years of working with dedicated local community organizations in areas known to have successful land-based whale watching opportunities, B.C. is now host to over 39 designated Whale Trail sites marked by interpretive panels and/or trail markers. Every Whale Trail panel highlights local information and marine mammal species that can be spotted in the area. Additionally, the Whale Trail B.C. contributes to conservation-based research by prompting people to report their sightings to the B.C. Cetacean Sightings Network, which is used to help monitor populations of cetaceans and sea turtles in B.C. The Whale Trail B.C. is generously supported in part by Mountain Equipment Co-op, WWF Canada, Patagonia, the Shaw Centre for the Salish Sea and Prince Rupert LNG, with additional panels funded in local areas by individuals and organizations.

To date, designated Whale Trail B.C. sites with interpretive panels include:
- Thieves Bay (Pender Island)
- Bellhouse Park (Galiano Island)
- Vancouver Aquarium Marine Science Centre (Vancouver)
- Shaw Ocean Discovery Centre (Sidney)
- Fred and Bette Cotton Park (Mayne Island)
- Lighthouse Park (West Vancouver)
- Summit Lodge Sea to Sky Gondola (Squamish)
- Whale Interpretive Centre (Telegraph Cove)
- Wild Pacific Trail (Ucluelet)
- Tonquin Trail (Tofino)
- Bamfield Marine Science Centre (Bamfield)
- Community Pier (Prince Rupert)
 
*Partners/sponsors:* The Whale Trail B.C. project is a collaborative partnership with the Whale Trail Organization, and is coordinated by Ocean Wise’s Coastal Ocean Research Institute. It includes many B.C. partners such as: The Whale Interpretive Centre, Saturna Island Marine Education and Research Society, Strawberry Isle Marine Research Society, B.C. Parks, Galiano Parks and Recreation Commission, Lighthouse Park Preservation Society, Pender Ocean Defenders, Magic Lake Property Owners Society, Raincoast Conservation Foundation, OrcaLab, Shaw Centre for the Salish Sea, The Wild Pacific Trail Society, Bowen Island Municipality, Bowen Island Conservancy, Bowen Nature Club, Mayne Island Conservation Society, The District of Ucluelet, The District of Tofino, The District of West Vancouver, The City of Prince Rupert, The Port of Prince Rupert, The Sea to Sky Gondola, Tla-o-qui-aht First Nation, The Bamfield Marine Sciences Centre, The Capital Regional District, Mayne Island Parks and JASCO Applied Sciences.

supportersCopy.en-US: Whale Trail B.C. is a collaborative partnership with the Whale Trail Organization, and is coordinated by Ocean Wise’s Coastal Ocean Research Institute.

subheader.en-US: Creating humpback whale catalogues for the south and central coast

copy.en-US:
Fisheries and Oceans Canada created a coast-wide humpback whale photo-identification catalogue in the early 2000’s, but discontinued this effort ten years later. To fill the gap, NGO-based researchers created catalogues for the south and central coasts. To ensure full coastal coverage, the NCCRI has created a Chatham Sound/Work Channel catalogue. By working collaboratively and sharing findings with the researchers maintaining the existing catalogues, we will help further the understanding of humpback whale habitat use, site fidelity and movements in B.C. as well as in north coast waters. To date, over 100 individual humpbacks whales have been identified using this region since 2014.

The NCCRI also actively engages the community through abundant outreach opportunities, including a bi-monthly North Coast Marine Speaker Series. This program also works with local government and industry to address issues of concern along the coast. A Mariner’s Guide to Whales, Dolphins and Porpoises in Western Canada [BV5] is a good example of this type of collaborative work.

subheader.en-US: Developing a current baseline for harbour porpoise occurrence and distribution to inform marine planning

copy.en-US: The Pacific population of harbour porpoise is currently listed as “Special Concern” under Canada’s Species at Risk Act (SARA). Harbour porpoises can be consistently found in the waters surrounding Prince Rupert, and are often in larger aggregations than is normally observed for this species. Harbour porpoise in this area are subjected to high levels of shipping traffic, which is likely to increase with the expansion of an existing container terminal and the development of energy export facilities in upcoming years. This increased industrialization may enhance the impact of the key threats identified in this species’ Management Plan, such as habitat degradation, toxic spills and acoustic disturbance. Utilizing a combination of land-based observation surveys of porpoises and passive acoustic monitoring, the NCCRI is evaluating the seasonal and daily patterns of habitat use by harbour porpoise in several locations of the Prince Rupert harbour and surrounding areas. This information is developing a current baseline for harbour porpoise occurrence and distribution to inform marine planning, and will also be used to identify appropriate conservation and threat mitigation actions.

title.en-US: Marine Mammals as Sentinels

copy.en-US: The marine environment is at the receiving end of thousands of chemicals being released intentionally or unintentionally every year. Persistent contaminants including polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs) are found throughout the global environment and accumulate in the aquatic food chain. Many marine mammals are long-lived, have a thick blubber layer and are at the top of the food chain, predisposing them to accumulating persistent organic pollutants (POPs) at harmful levels. Ocean Wise Research Team has been monitoring contaminant levels and their potential associated health risks in various marine mammal species such as harbour seals, killer whales, beluga whales and ringed seals.

projectTitle.en-US: Contaminant Monitoring in British Columbia Killer Whales and Harbour Seals
Climate Change, Organic Contaminants and The Health of Beluga Whales in The Western Arctic
Climate Change, Long Term Trends of Mercury Exposure and The Health of Ringed Seals in The Eastern Arctic

title.en-US: Oil Spill Science

copy.en-US: Oil spills provide poignant reminders of the fragility of aquatic ecosystems. Protecting ocean environments requires a mix of best practices, regulations, operational readiness and up-to-date scientific information. Given the complex nature of hydrocarbon sources in any marine environment, data are best generated in a way that enables a distinction between natural sources (e.g. plant materials, geological sources) and a long history of anthropogenic sources (e.g. petrogenic or pyrogenic sources). As part of [Pollution Tracker](http://pollutiontracker.org/contaminants/pahs/), hydrocarbons along the BC coast are being monitored, providing important baseline.

title.en-US: Safe Traditional Seafoods

copy.en-US: Ocean pollution presents a threat to marine life, and those that depend on it. Coastal aboriginal communities in British Columbia and elsewhere in Canada rely much more heavily on aquatic foods than the average Canadian. Ocean Wise has been conducting research in close collaborations with coastal First Nations to document contaminant exposure (consumption), contaminant levels in different Traditional Foods, and risk-benefit analysis in a manner that is enabling for consumers and forward-looking.

projectTitle.en-US: Impacts of Fukushima Nuclear Radiation on Traditional Seafoods from The West Coast of Vancouver Island

title.en-US: Vulnerable Species and Habitats

copy.en-US: With a long history of overfishing and industrial contamination, there are number of vulnerable species and habitats in Howe Sound that warrant specific consideration.   There are at least 25 Species at Risk that use or once used Howe Sound as an important component of their habitat.

projectTitle.en-US: Next-Generation Biodiversity Monitoring Using DNA Barcodes

title.en-US: Conservation

copy.en-US: Ecological research is most valuable if it can be applied towards achieving tangible conservation outcomes.  Our objective is to enable conservation action that improves the protection and restoration of priority species, habitats and ecosystems functions.  In doing this work, we will collaborate with scientists, organizations, agencies, and communities who work and live within and on coastal ecosystems.  By bringing together different types of knowledge, including traditional ecological knowledge, practical experience and observations, and scientific research, we aim to connect people with the information they need to use the best practices possible when interacting with coastal habitats.

title.en-US: Ecological Monitoring and Citizen Science

copy.en-US: The research team aims to track the status and trends of key species and habitats using science, traditional knowledge, and citizen engagement.

title.en-US: Walruses

copy.en-US: The Vancouver Aquarium is home to two young walruses, Balzak and Lakina. These two animals are part of an international research program using animals located at Aquariums across the globe. The overall goal of the research is to understand how climate change and other environmental disturbances are impacting walrus populations in the Arctic.

subheader.en-US: The Vancouver Aquarium is home to two young walruses, Balzak and Lakina

copy.en-US:
The Vancouver Aquarium is home to two young walruses, Balzak and Lakina. These two animals are part of an international research program using animals located at Aquariums across the globe. The overall goal of the research is to understand how climate change and other environmental disturbances are impacting walrus populations in the Arctic. 

Climate change is predicted to impact walruses through several environmental changes. Changes in the extent of sea ice cover will cause animals to spend a greater amount of time in the water. This behavioural change likely has a significant energetic cost, that translates into changes in food requirements. At the same time, changes in ocean temperatures and acidity are predicted to impact the distribution and abundance of prey items important to walruses. While mathematical models exist for predicting how such changes might affect walrus food requirements and health, these are not based on hard data. 

In some cases, a lack of sea ice means animals are forced to gather in large herds on land. This unusual behaviour has already resulted in several Unusual Mortality Events (UMEs) in Alaska. In addition to assumedly causing changes in energy requirements and food intake, these dense gatherings also give rise to unique disease challenges.

Walruses at the Vancouver Aquarium are involved in studies to measure the energy requirements of walruses in air and water, test a technique for measuring the size and condition of walruses remotely, and investigate the development of immune function as walruses develop.

### 1. Metabolic rates of young walruses in air and water
Goal: Determine how the resting metabolism in air and water of young walruses changes during the year and with age.

In this study, the metabolic rate (rate of energy use) of the two walruses will be measured both while floating quietly in water and while on land. Rates of oxygen consumption (= energy use) will be measured while their head is inside of a floating dome using standard respirometry techniques.  We are also training the walruses to breathe through a special tube. This is part of a joint project with Oceanografic Valencia to test an alternate means of determining rates of oxygen consumption.

The walruses also spend time in a dry metabolic chamber (a small quiet room), to measure how much energy they use while on land. Eventually, the energy expenditure of the resting walruses will be measured both on dry land and while resting on a sheet of ice. 

The results of this study will allow scientists to more accurately predict the food requirements of walruses in the wild, and to determine the possible impact of changes in behaviour. 

### 2. Determining growth and size of walruses.
The walruses have been trained for collection of a standard set of morphological (body shape/size) measurements. These include length, body mass, and girth at 2 key sites (chest and hips). These measures are important for understanding and predicting the relationship between growth and food intake in this species.

We are also developing a technique that allows remote measurements of walrus size using a paired set of digital cameras. The walruses in our collection provide us the opportunity to develop and validate the accuracy of this technique as a possible tool to study the health of wild walrus populations.

### 3. Testing immune function in walruses
Almost no information is available on the hematology (blood profile) and immune function of walruses. In tandem with staff at the Vancouver Aquarium’s Animal Health Dept., we are developing a study to track changes in normal blood values and develop a tool to evaluate the health status of walruses in the wild.

title.en-US: Steller Sea Lions

copy.en-US: Steller sea lions are the largest type of sea lion in the world. Since 1980, more than 80 percent of the Steller sea lion population has disappeared, leaving the current wild population with less than 75,000 individuals. In 1990, Steller sea lions were listed as "threatened" under the United States Endangered Species Act. In 1997, the U.S. National Marine Fisheries Service reclassified some populations of Steller sea lions in Alaska as "endangered".

subheader.en-US: Steller Sea Lions are the largest type of sea lion in the world

copy.en-US:
The Problem: Disappearing sea lions.
[Steller sea lions](https://www.vanaqua.org/learn/aquafacts/otters-and-pinnipeds/steller-sea-lions) are the largest type of sea lion in the world. Since 1980, more than 80 percent of the Steller sea lion population has disappeared, leaving the current wild population with less than 75,000 individuals. In 1990, Steller sea lions were listed as "threatened" under the United States Endangered Species Act. In 1997, the U.S. National Marine Fisheries Service reclassified some populations of Steller sea lions in Alaska as "endangered".

*The Big Question: Why are Steller sea lions disappearing?*
Scientists are currently trying to figure out why Steller sea lion populations are declining. Possible reasons for this include an increase in parasites, disease, predation by killer whales, environmental factors, and nutritional stress caused by natural changes in the abundance or quality of key prey species, or by competition with other species, including humans, for food.

*The Solution: Sea lion research at the Vancouver Aquarium Marine Science Centre.*
In 1993 the Aquarium partnered with the North Pacific Universities Marine Mammal Research Consortium and scientists at [the University of British Columbia](http://www.marinemammal.org/) in a unique joint research program that uses trained Steller sea lions to try to understand what is causing population declines in the wild. 

Scientists perform studies with a group of Steller sea lions, held at both the Vancouver Aquarium and UBC’s [Open Water Research Station](https://www.sealionresearch.org/). Many of the studies explore the possible effects of changes in the types and amounts of prey that are available in the North Pacific have on sea lion condition, health and energy balance. This includes studies measuring how much food/energy sea lions need to perform different activities (resting, swimming, growing, staying warm, etc.) and determining the nutritional value to sea lions of different prey. Studies are also designed to develop scientific techniques and new technologies to enable scientists to better study sea lions in the wild. 

This unique research program involves researchers from around the globe. It has resulted in over 70 publications and directly contributed to management plans aimed at conserving Steller sea lions in the wild. 

Current research projects include:

- Determining “normal” blood values in Steller sea lions of different ages to assess health in the wild.
- Developing a new technique to quickly determine the physical condition of sea lions.
- Documenting “normal” cardiac function of sea lions as a clinical tool and to understand their exceptional diving abilities.

title.en-US: Northern Fur Seals

copy.en-US: Northern fur seals live predominantly in the North Pacific and Bering Sea, breeding on only a handful of islands. They were nearly wiped out in Alaska in the early 1900s for their valuable fur. After bring granted international protection in 1911, their populations largely recovered. However, pup production in the Pribilof Islands in the Bering Sea (the main breeding site) has decreased about 50% since the 1970s, and continues to drop about 6–7% per year. This has caused them to be listed as "vulnerable" under the U.S. Endangered Species Act and by the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

subheader.en-US: Northern fur seals live predominantly in the north Pacific and Bearing Sea

copy.en-US:
[Northern fur seals](https://www.vanaqua.org/learn/aquafacts/otters-and-pinnipeds/northern-fur-seals) live predominantly in the North Pacific and Bering Sea, breeding on only a handful of islands. They were nearly wiped out in Alaska in the early 1900s for their valuable fur. After bring granted international protection in 1911, their populations largely recovered. However, pup production in the Pribilof Islands in the Bering Sea (the main breeding site) has decreased about 50% since the 1970s, and continues to drop about 6–7% per year. This has caused them to be listed as "vulnerable" under the U.S. Endangered Species Act and by the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

Scientists are involved in an intense research program to determine the causes of the decline. Possible factors include killer whale predation, competition with fisheries, and the effects of climate change (including changes in the type or location of available prey). In 2008, the Vancouver Aquarium partnered with the North Pacific Universities Marine Mammal Research Consortium and scientists at [the University of British Columbia](https://www.marinemammal.org) in a unique joint research program that used trained fur seals to understand the roots of the declines and how to best conserve the species.

A group of 5 northern fur seals are permanently housed at the Vancouver Aquarium. These highly trained animals participate in research projects that help shed light on what might be negatively affecting their conspecifics in the wild. Areas of research include understanding how the food requirements of these animals change as they mature, how food intake naturally varies during the year, their capacity to withstand different environmental temperatures, how they can compensate for periods of inadequate nutrition, and how to determine the health and nutritional status of fur seals in the wild.

This unique research program involves researchers from around the globe. It has resulted in over 70 publications and directly contributed to management plans aimed at conserving northern fur seals in the wild. 

Current research projects include:
- Measuring the potential impact of biologging tags used to study fur seals in the wild.
- Documenting “normal” cardiac function of fur seals as a clinical tool and to understand their exceptional diving abilities.

subheader.en-US: Ensuring the well-being and welfare of animals under human care and in the wild

copy.en-US:
The primary goal of the Animal Health Department is to ensure the well-being and welfare of animals in the Aquarium’s diverse animal collection and to care for, rehabilitate, and release rescued individuals taken into the [Marine Mammal Rescue Centre](https://rescue.ocean.org/). 

The Animal Health Department also has a vibrant research program that furthers the Aquarium’s goal of improving the lives of animals maintained temporarily or permanently under human care, as well as animals in the wild. Animal Health staff are involved in studies that range from ad hoc case studies of individual animals to fully planned research projects that address aspects of animal physiology, veterinary medicine, genetics, and disease. Studies are also conducted that directly relate to evaluating Ocean Health through disease tracking among wild animals and disentanglement efforts by trained Animal Health staff. 

Some of the research results directly from working with animals under their care. Other projects are the product of cooperative research with scientists and veterinarians from around the globe. 

Recent studies include:
- Mapping the genome of beluga whales and Northern sea otters to provide a cutting-edge diagnostic tool for individual animal and ecosystem health.
- Investigating the causes of “sea star wasting disease” along the West Coast.
- Understanding the physiology of diving in a number of species of marine mammals.
- Developing methods of safely implanting long-term “life history tags” in several species of pinnipeds as part of an international species conservation effort.

title.en-US: Propagation

subheader.en-US: Responsible propagation and cultivation of new and existing species at the Vancouver Aquarium

overlay.en-US: Propagation and cultivation of new and existing species

copy.en-US:
Visitors to the Vancouver Aquarium marvel at the variety of different species on display. But members of the Propagation Program are concerned with more than ensuring the tanks are filled with interesting creatures. They are also on a mission to fulfill the Aquarium’s outreach, research, and the conservation goals through responsible propagation and cultivation of new and existing species. 

Team members study the best conditions for raising species, many of which have never been reared in an aquarium. They document the physical development of animals that have never been previously described by scientists. They directly contribute to the conservation of endangered species by raising and releasing animals into their natural habitat. When that is not possible, they work to maintain a breeding population in the lab, to preserve the species until conditions improve for reintroduction.

title.en-US: Amphibian Ark

copy.en-US: The vast majority of frogs today are threatened with extinction. In the past 10 years alone it is estimated that at least 165 species of amphibians have become extinct. Aquarium researchers are trying to stop that trend.

subheader.en-US: The vast majority of frogs today are threatened with extinction

copy.en-US:
In the past 10 years alone it is estimated that at least 165 species of amphibians have become extinct. Aquarium researchers are trying to stop that trend.

Ocean Wise Research has joined forces with zoos and aquariums around the world to try and stop hundreds of species from vanishing forever in a global effort called Amphibian Ark (AArk). AArk’s goal is to raise awareness about amphibian vulnerability and rescue at least 500 of the most threatened species. These species will be protected and bred in secure facilities at zoos and aquariums until the animals can one day be released back into nature. Currently the Aquarium maintains an “assurance-population” for several species of critically endangered frogs.

The threat isn’t just in far-away jungles. The Oregon spotted frog (*Rana pretiosa*) is the most endangered amphibian in Canada and only found in a small area of British Columbia. Habitat destruction and the introduction of non-native species into the Fraser River Valley have caused the Oregon spotted frog population to decline rapidly in recent years. In an effort to protect the species, the Aquarium joined the Oregon Spotted Frog Recovery Team in 2000. In 2009 the Aquarium received adult Oregon spotted frogs to form the first assurance population for the species to keep them safe in case the wild population should be lost. In 2010 these frogs were bred at the Vancouver Aquarium for the first time ever in an aquarium environment. Later that year thousands of cultured tadpoles and juvenile frogs were released into natural habitats near established populations in the wild and the Aquarium continues to release offspring produced annually. 

The Rocky Mountain population of the Northern leopard frog (*Lithobates pipiens*) is another species at high risk and is British Columbia’s most endangered amphibian, with a small isolated population found only in a small area of South Eastern B.C. Populations of northern leopard frogs declined sharply across much of western Canada in the 1970s. To help improve the chances of survival, the Aquarium joined the Northern Leopard Frog Recovery Team and started an assurance population for them at the Vancouver Aquarium. Eggs collected from the wild are raised to adult, then bred onsite with the resulting offspring released into their native range to help boost the population.

Current research goals include:
- Examining ways to improve fertility rates of Oregon Spotted Frogs and Northern Leopard Frogs to maximize the Aquarium’s conservation release efforts
- Test the use of a novel aquaponics plant culture system for maintaining water quality within the frog greenhouse life support systems
- Testing the efficacy of rooftop green waste composting systems and the palatability of composting worms as a food source for the frog collection
- Exploring optimal conditions for rearing and display of new amphibian species, including Panamanian golden frogs, Atelopus zeteki

subheader.en-US: Ocean plastic pollution is a truly global problem and the Arctic is no exception

copy.en-US:
Ocean Wise researchers are studying the prevalence and impacts of microplastics in Arctic sea water and sediments, and in marine life from zooplankton to beluga whales.

- Microplastics in Sea Water and Sediments 
- Effects of Microplastics on Zooplankton Health
- Microplastics in the Beluga Food Web

subheader.en-US: Ocean Wise researchers are studying the biology and ecology of Arctic marine mammals

copy.en-US:
Ocean Wise researchers are studying the biology and ecology of Arctic marine mammals, including important and iconic species such as beluga whales, narwhals, seals and walruses. Researchers at the Coastal Ocean Research Institute’s Ocean Pollution Program study the extent and impacts of contaminants in ringed seals and beluga whales.

- Beluga whale social interactions and communications
- Contaminants, Climate change and beluga whale health 
- Mercury in ringed seals 
- Narwhal habitat use
- Walrus energetics

subheader.en-US: Surveying and analysing underwater Arctic ecology

copy.en-US:
Reliable data and ongoing monitoring of the Arctic Ocean is crucial for understanding the changes underway in Canada’s North. By collaborating with Arctic knowledge research partners and Inuit communities, Ocean Wise Research sends diving teams to coastal regions across Nunavut, where they collect sorely needed data about marine biodiversity. In the future, these data can be compared against future monitoring results and help identify sensitive ecological areas that require future protection. Ocean Wise Research is also collecting water samples from across the Arctic region to establish the presence and absence of marine life through DNA barcoding.

View our reports on Subtidal Arctic Ecology:

- [NES report 2015 FINAL](//assets.ctfassets.net/fsquhe7zbn68/2Z2RyeqIzSCUc8U8qEeKae/1df55f9a8037067e187d8a9200016105/NES_report_2015_FINAL.pdf)
- [NES report 2016 Final](//assets.ctfassets.net/fsquhe7zbn68/1rchVaut1ao0Mc8Sgc4uW6/64385ea36aa9cdab77948a02743ababa/NES_report_2016_Final.pdf)
- [Ocean Wise 2017 AMEBP Final Report](//assets.ctfassets.net/fsquhe7zbn68/7eXZLp5SO4OgKKycgaM60S/b2a3e690823a871e2a0b9588b9aa75ec/OceanWise_2017_AMEBP_Final_Report.pdf)
