title.en-US: Plastics Lab

copy.en-US: Contamination of marine ecosystems with microplastics is now recognized as a serious and growing threat to sealife. The Ocean Wise Plastics Lab, established in 2014 is an *Environmental Microplastics Facility*, which aims to deliver cutting-edge technical insight into the source, transport, fate and effects related to microplastics in Canada’s aquatic environments (both freshwater and marine). The Lab utilizes state-of-the-art analytical techniques and instrumentation including the high-resolution Fourier Transform Infrared spectrometer to identify plastic polymers in fragment and fibers down to 5 microns (0.005 mm) in size, and employs 12 research staff working on microplastics in wastewater treatment, home laundry, seawater, zooplankton, mussels, and ocean food webs.

subheader.en-US: There's an average of 3,200 particles of microplastics per cubic meter of seawater in the Strait of Georgia

copy.en-US:
Environmental microplastic can originate from several mechanisms including disintegration of larger plastic debris, atmospheric deposition, emission with stormwater, sewer outflows and effluents form wastewater treatment plant (WWTP), as well as treated sludge that has been applied to agricultural or other lands. However, the extend to which any of these processes contribute to the plastic contamination is largely uncertain.

The Plastics Lab team reported an average of 3,200 particles of microplastics per cubic meter of seawater in the coastal Strait of Georgia, with the majority being fibres. These observations in the nearshore environment of the NE Pacific Ocean raised the hypothesis that sewage effluent containing microfibers from textiles may contribute significantly to microplastic contamination of the coastal waters of BC. Together with Mountain Equipment Co-op (MEC), Arcteryx, REI and Patagonia, the Plastics Lab is working on a research project to characterize textile materials using high-resolution Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectrometry and evaluating the extent to which different material types shed microfibres through laundering. In addition, in collaboration with MetroVancouver the group is investigating the fate of microplastics in several wastewater facilities in the region. A part of this collaborative effort is a [study published in 2018]( https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0025326X18304053) documenting an annual input of approximately 30 billion microplastics into the immediate aquatic environment of one of the largest treatment facilities in the region. With this study highlighting the importance of treatment plants as sources of microplastics, further research is being conducted to delineate factors influencing microplastic retention and emissions through regional wastewater facilities. The multi-partner supported research conducted by the Plastics Lab has strong potential to inform product design, source control, wastewater engineering, regulations and consumer choices, by providing basic information on the contribution of textiles to microplastics in the aquatic environment.

projectTitle.en-US: What is the extent of microplastic contamination in the Arctic?

subheader.en-US: This research provides an in depth picture of microplastics distribution from Norway to Greenland to the Eastern Canadian Arctic and the Beaufort Sea

copy.en-US:
Previous research by the Plastics Lab researchers revealed the widespread distribution of suspected microplastics in seawater in the NE Pacific Ocean with an average of 3200 plastic particles per cubic meter of seawater reported in samples from the Strait of Georgia. While concerns about debris and microplastic pollution have largely focused on areas close to human activities, remote regions are far from immune. The two key attributes that make plastic products so desirable to consumers – durability and light weight – allow for their easy transport with ocean currents. The presence of microplastics in the Arctic was recently reported in sea water and ice cores and there is potential for huge quantities to be released as a consequence of sea ice melting due to climate change.

The Plastics Lab established a collaborative field platform for the collection of microplastics samples aboard Arctic science vessels (CCGS Sir Wilfrid Laurier, CCGS Louis St Laurent, and the MV One Ocean Navigator). Through the collection of sediment, surface waters as well as water at different depths, this research provides, for the first time, an in depth picture of microplastics distribution from Norway to Greenland to the Eastern Canadian Arctic and the Beaufort Sea. This spatial data is being used to assess the effects of biological and physical oceanographic factors on microplastic distribution in the Canadian Arctic, and will serve to populate a risk-based evaluation for arctic biota, including such species as char and cod.

### This project will provide valuable information on the state of microplastics contamination in Arctic food webs

Research by the Plastics Lab scientists showed ready ingestion of microplastic particles by two zooplankton species in the NE Pacific Ocean (Neocalanus cristatus and Euphausia pacifica). It was estimated that individual adult salmon in coastal BC could be consuming as much as 90 microplastic particles per day. Ingestion of microplastics by Arctic zooplankton, fish and potentially beluga whales raises a similar concern: are microplastics being ingested at the bottom of the Arctic food chain in a manner that delivers plastic to such species as Arctic cod, char or beluga whales?

Studies have revealed that plastic litter is found in the Arctic with macro-plastic ingestion by seabirds and cetaceans. There have been no reports of ingestion of microplastics in arctic biota and our understanding of biological risks related to microplastics remains largely confined to laboratory studies. Scientist at the Plastics Lab are collecting samples at the different level of the Arctic food web: from tiny zooplankton to various species of fish to beluga whale stomachs. The Plastics Lab has developed close relationship with the Inuvialuit community of Tuktoyaktuk which allows us to collect samples from their traditionally harvested beluga whales. This will provide valuable information on the state of microplastics contamination in Arctic food webs. Such questions are bound to have bearing on the health of indigenous marine foods that are valued by the Inuit.

projectTitle.en-US: Are microplastics being incorporated into Arctic food webs

subheader.en-US: This project will provide valuable information on the state of microplastics contamination in Arctic food webs

copy.en-US:
OPRP research showed ready ingestion of microplastic particles by two zooplankton species in the NE Pacific Ocean (Neocalanus cristatus and Euphausia pacifica). It was estimated that individual adult salmon in coastal BC could be consuming as much as 90 microplastic particles per day. Ingestion of microplastics by Arctic zooplankton, fish and potentially beluga whales raises a similar concern: are microplastics being ingested at the bottom of the Arctic food chain in a manner that delivers plastic to such species as Arctic cod, char or beluga whales?

Studies have revealed that plastic litter is found in the Arctic with macro-plastic ingestion by seabirds and cetaceans. There have been no reports of ingestion of microplastics in arctic biota and our understanding of biological risks related to microplastics remains largely confined to laboratory studies. OPRP is collecting samples at the different level of the Arctic food web: from tiny zooplankton to various species of fish to beluga whale stomachs. OPRP developed close relationship with the Inuvialuit community of Tuktoyaktuk which allows us to collect samples from their traditionally harvested beluga whales. This will provide valuable information on the state of microplastics contamination in Arctic food webs. Such questions are bound to have bearing on the health of indigenous marine foods that are valued by the Inuit.

Eric Solomon is Director of Arctic Programs at Ocean Wise. He leads Ocean Wise’s Arctic research, conservation and education initiatives, and works with Arctic Indigenous communities, researchers, policy-makers, educators and the general public to improve knowledge of and dialogue on this important region. He has dedicated much of the last decade toward working with Arctic Indigenous communities and scientific researchers to facilitate co-creation of research that addresses issues of local concern. A Laureate of the Arctic Inspiration Prize, Eric was a co-creator and oversees the operation of Ikaarvik: Barriers to Bridges, a program that works with northern Indigenous youth to be the bridge between scientific research and Arctic communities. He holds a bachelor’s in Psychology, a master’s in Marine Ecology and advanced graduate studies in Science Education, none of which compares to what he has learned while working with Indigenous communities across the North.

title.en-US: Propagation and Research Lab

copy.en-US: The Vancouver Aquarium's Propagation and Research Lab has been operating for over 30 years and is a recognized leader amongst zoos and aquariums around the world.

subheader.en-US: A recognized leader amongst zoos and aquariums

copy.en-US: The Vancouver Aquarium's Propagation and Research Lab has been operating for over 30 years and is a recognized leader amongst zoos and aquariums around the world in the culturing of temperate marine fish and invertebrates. To date, the lab has reared over 70 species of marine fish and 20 crustacean species from the Pacific Northwest. Rearing efforts not only allow Aquarium biologists to document the early life history of these animals - many for the first time - but also to produce animals for display, for education, and to supply research collaborators at other facilities. In addition to taking advantage of natural reproduction that occurs in the diverse collection of local fish and invertebrates from our displays, the lab also has an active field component that searches for new and interesting early life history research opportunities around coastal BC.

title.en-US: Arctic Lab

copy.en-US: Refining husbandry techniques of wild-caught Arctic fishes and invertabrates.

subheader.en-US: Refining husbandry techniques of wild-caught Arctic fishes and invertabrates

copy.en-US:
The Vancouver Aquarium's Arctic Lab has been operating since 2009 and was originally set up to allow for the temporary holding and refining of husbandry techniques of wild-caugh Arctic fishes and invertebrates prior to being put on display. In 2014, a second and expanded Arctic rearing lab was designed and built with the specific goal of being able to not only hold surplus Arctic animals, but to facilitate the captive reproduction and rearing of many of those species. To date, the Arctic lab has successfully reproduced over a dozen species of Arctic marine fish and invertebrates. The lab was the first facility in North America and possibly the world to rear Arctic cod, a key species in the Arctic food web. Rearing efforts not only allow Aquarium biologists to document the early life history of these animals - many for the first time - but also to produce animals for display, for education, and to supply research collaborators from other facilities.

The Arctic Lab biologists also work in collaboration with other departments from the Aquarium and the Coastal Ocean Research Institute to conduct SCUBA diving-based fieldwork in the Arctic. Aquarium divers carry out Arctic species diversity surveys, photographic and video documentation of Arctic marine life, specimen collecting and educational outreach initiatives. For the last 3-4 years we have been conducting dive surveys around the Cambridge Bay area (Victoria Island, Nunavut) in collaboration with Polar Knowledge Canada, based out of the government's new Canadian High Arctic Research Station (CHARS). This year we are planning to expand the dive surveys to remote dive sites much further north as we team up with One Ocean Expeditions.

title.en-US: Jellyfish Lab

copy.en-US: The Vancouver Aquarium's Jellyfish Lab started in 2005 with just a hondful of local jellyfish species. Today, it is home to over 30 different species from around the world.

subheader.en-US: Home to over 30 species from around the world

copy.en-US:
The Vancouver Aquarium's Jellyfish Lab started in 2005 with just a hondful of local jellyfish species. Today, it is home to over 30 different species from around the world. We colture jellies not only for display, but for education and research as well. We are continually tring to propagate new local and exotic jellyfish species to expand our knowledge of life history, tank design and environmental requirements. Our animals, knowledge and expertise help other researchers who are looking to study, culture or display jellyfish.

Successfully raising different species of kellyfish is part science and part art. Jellies require specialized, circular tanks called kreisels, which mimic the open ocean environment. Jellies often need very specific environmental parameters, including temperature, salinity, diet and photoperiod. These optimal conditions can change, as the kelly progresses through its different, distinct life history phases: planula larva, polyp, ephyra, and adult medusa stages. Raising jellyfish in the lab leabs to an understanding of how water conditions and food affect the growth and success of jellyfish. This provides insight into how best to care for them in the Aquarium, and how populations may be affected by environmental changes.

Danny Kent has worked at the Vancouver Aquarium for 30 years in a variety of roles.  As Curator of the Propagation department he oversees the aquarium biologists and associated animal collection involved in a variety of culture and rearing programs throughout the facility.  This diverse collection ranges from endangered local amphibian species to Arctic marine fish and invertebrates.  He specializes the early life history, taxonomic identification and illustration of marine fish larvae.  As an avid SCUBA diver and photographer he has had the opportunity collect and photograph specimens from coastal BC, the Philippines, the Amazon and the Canadian high Arctic.

Mackenzie Neale is the Assistant Curator of the Propagation department and has worked at the Vancouver Aquarium for the last 20 years.  She specializes in jellyfish husbandry and has worked with more than 50 different species of jellies from around the world.  As a member of the Aquarium’s dive team she has had the opportunity to dive in many places along the BC coast as well as in the Arctic.

David Caughlan is a Senior Aquarium Biologist in the Propagation Department. He is presently in charge of the fish and invertebrates in our Arctic collection. David is a jack of all trades and has worked and volunteered in many other departments within the Aquarium including: the Carpentry shop; Fish Research; Marine Mammals; Amazon Gallery, BC Waters as well as  internationally in aquariums in both Eastern and Western Australia.

Darren Smy has more than 17 years’ experience working with reptiles and amphibians in a professional capacity and over 28 years personally, both in Canada and the UK. During this time, he has successfully reproduced over 35 species of amphibians. Many of those bred are classified as threatened or endangered, including for the first time under human care, the Oregon spotted frog (Rana pretiosa), Canada’s most endangered amphibian. Darren is the Vancouver Aquarium representative for the Oregon spotted frog Recovery Team.

After becoming captivated by fish during his time at university, Kris Rossing graduated from UBC with a degree in Marine Biology and sought gainful employment at the Vancouver Aquarium to further develop his skills and knowledge. It wouldn’t be long before he became enamored by the Aquariums’ amphibian population, though, and they quickly became his new passion. Over a decade later, Kris is proud to still be a part of the Vancouver Aquariums’ only animal conservation program; breeding endangered BC frogs in captivity as part of a provincial recovery effort to ensure the survival of these important and fascinating creatures.

Crystal Kulcsar has been a fulltime Aquarium Biologist at the Vancouver Aquarium for the past six years. She has a degree in biology and currently specializes in jellyfish display, husbandry and breeding.  She has also worked with Arctic fish and invertebrates, amphibians, and with larval fish culture. During her free time she enjoys traveling to new countries and volunteer diving with the Howe Sound Research and Conservation group.

Boaz Hung has been working at the Vancouver Aquarium for over six years.  He currently specializes in temperate larval fish and invertebrate reproduction, culture and rearing.  As and active member of the Aquarium’s dive team he has been involved with research and specimen collecting dives in coastal BC and the Canadian Arctic.

Mitchell Hoyle was born and raised in Vancouver and got his bachelor’s degree in Biology at the University of Western Ontario. Following his childhood dream of working with frogs, Mitchell volunteered in animal husbandry at the aquarium for a year and a half before becoming an Assistant Aquarium Biologist with the Propagation team. He can be found working in the Frog, Jellyfish, Arctic and Fish Lab sections.

Raymundo Aguas is an Aquarium Biologist in the Propagation Department. He has recently joined the team to develop expertise in animal husbandry and rearing techniques of jellyfish and Arctic fishes and invertebrates. He has broad interests, and as an Aquarium Biologist he has also worked with temperate water species of marine invertebrates and fishes from British Columbia, and tropical fresh water fishes from the Amazon.

Dave Carlson is a Senior Aquarium Biologist who specializes in larval fish and invertebrate reproduction, culture and rearing. Over the last decade, he has helped document and preserve many life history stages for several temperate fish and invertebrate species.  He is an active member in the home hobbyist industry and is an avid fisherman.

projectTitle.en-US: Microplastic contamination of coastal British Columbia ecosystem

subheader.en-US: Reporting on the current and future state of microplastic contamination of BC's nearshore ecosystem

copy.en-US:
Research from the Plastic Lab has pointed to the elevated levels of microplastics, up to 3,200 particles per cubic meter, in the nearshore surface water of BC. To understand the fate and potential biological impacts of microplastics in the nearshore habitat of coastal BC, the Plastics Lab studies these contaminants in local mussels, sediments and the Straight of Georgia seawater.
Blue mussels (Mytilus spp.) are an ecologically important species often referred to as “ecosystem engineers” due to the complex 3D habitats they create in coastal environments. Because blue mussels are filter feeding organisms, they are exposed to a myriad of marine pollutants daily. Individuals are used globally to assess ocean pollution through the International Mussel Watch program. Through a combination of field- and lab-based experiments researchers at the Plastics Lab are investigating microplastic accumulation by British Columbia blue mussels, and evaluating if these organisms could be used as bioindicators of aquatic microplastic contamination. Furthermore, microplastic measurements in BC’s blue mussels are being carried out as part of the coast-wide monitoring program, the [PollutionTracker](http://pollutiontracker.org/). Collectively with measurements of microplastic abundance in local sediments as well as Straight of Georgia seawater, the research at the Plastic Lab builds knowledge on the state of microplastic contamination in the BC’s coastal ecosystem.

projectTitle.en-US: Microplastic contamination of coastal British Columbia

subheader.en-US: Researching microplastic contamination in BC's marine species

copy.en-US:
Coastal British Columbia is home to abundant and diverse sea life. Researchers at Ocean Wise conduct research on microplastic contamination in BC’s marine species as well as their habitat to better understand the scale of the issue in the region. Our projects include:

- Microplastic abundance and ingestion in BC’s blue mussels
- Microplastic abundance in BC sediments and Straight of Georgia seawater

projectTitle.en-US: Tracing sources and transport of microplastics from land to sea

subheader.en-US: Land-based processes play a significant role in supplying microplastics

copy.en-US:
Land-based processes are recognized to play a significant role in supplying microplastics into the environment. Research conducted at Ocean Wise aims to understand the extent to which various processes on land contribute to environmental microplastic contamination, including:
- Microfiber release into domestic wastewater during home laundry
- Microplastic emission with treated domestic wastewater via treatment plants
- Microplastic emission via combined sewer outflows and stormwater

subheader.en-US: Ocean plastic pollution is a truly global problem and the Arctic is no exception

copy.en-US:
Ocean Wise researchers are studying the prevalence and impacts of microplastics in Arctic sea water and sediments, and in marine life from zooplankton to beluga whales.

- Microplastics in sea water and sediments
- Effects of microplastics on zooplankton health
- Microplastics in the beluga food web

Jeremy Heywood is the Diving and Boating Safety Officer at the Ocean Wise Vancouver Aquarium, a position he has held since 2009. He is responsible for the implementation of the Ocean Wise diving safety program, including diver training, protocol development and operational oversight, both in-house and in the field, and he manages the boating safety program. Jeremy also directs the Ocean Wise scientific diving program in Canada’s Arctic.

title.en-US: Plastics Lab

subheader.en-US: Delivering cutting-edge technical insight into microplastics in Canada's aquatic environments

overlay.en-US: Delivering cutting-edge technical insight into microplastics

copy.en-US: Plastic litter has globally been recognized as a major threat to marine ecosystems, but increasing reports of microplastics (items < 5mm) have heightened concerns about plastic pollution in the world’s oceans. Microplastics are broadly categorized according to their origin into: 1. Primary microplastics, which are deliberately manufactured industrial plastic resin pellets (nurdles) or microbeads used in personal care products; and 2. Secondary microplastics, which are the breakdown products from larger items, such as food and beverage containers or fibers from synthetic ropes and clothing.

position.en-US: DVM, Msc, Dipl. ACZM; Vancouver Aquarium Veterinarian

copy.en-US:
Recognized world-wide for his high standards of veterinary care, Dr. Haulena is the Vancouver Aquarium’s veterinarian. In addition to his veterinary degree, Dr. Haulena has a Master’s degree in pathobiology and is a Diplomate of the American College of Zoological Medicine.

Veterinary students from around the world study aquatic animal medicine each year under the direction of Dr. Haulena. He serves as Adjunct Assistant Professor in the College of Veterinary Medicine at North Carolina State University and Adjunct Professor at the University of British Columbia Fisheries Centre.

Dr. Haulena's professional affiliations include the International Association for Aquatic Animal Medicine, Wildlife Disease Association and the American Association of Zoological Veterinarians. He has authored over 30 scientific journal articles and book chapters.

__Areas of Expertise__
- Medical management of aquatic animals, particularly marine mammals, 
- Innovation in diagnostic methods such as MRIs, endoscopy and sonography
- Developing safe anaesthetic protocols and improving surgical techniques
Lorem ipsum

Dr. Rosen is a research scientist at the University of British Columbia who has been leading the research efforts with the marine mammals maintained at the Vancouver Aquarium since 1995. His research primarily investigates the bioenergetics (energy requirements and expenditures), physiology, and nutrition of marine mammals. Its focus is to understand the root causes of population changes by investigating the interactions between the physiology of individual animals and biotic and abiotic environmental changes. In 2018 he was appointed Coordinator of Collections Research at the Vancouver Aquarium, facilitating all of the research conducted with the institution’s in-house collections.

__Areas of Expertise__
-	Marine mammal bioenergetics and nutrition
-	Conservation physiology
